00039 #ifndef LIBCURIE_IMMUTABLE_H
00040 #define LIBCURIE_IMMUTABLE_H
00041 
00042 /* making immutable copies of strings may help reduce the likelihood of
00043    memory leaks by making sure all immutable copies only exist exactly once
00044    in the process space, as well as prevent improper access to these strings
00045    (such as inadvertedly modifying them */
00046 
00047 /*@notnull@*/ /*@observer@*/ const char *str_immutable (/*@notnull@*/ /*@returned@*/ const char *);
00048 
00049 /* similarly, non-string data should be storable in this way, so here we go. */
00050 
00051 /*@notnull@*/ /*@observer@*/ const void *immutable (/*@notnull@*/ /*@returned@*/ const void *, unsigned long);
00052 
00053 /* this function is used to force locking of all the current pages that are used
00054    to store new immutable data. the idea is that if you know you wont be storing
00055    (much) new stuff anytime soon, you can call this function and immediately get
00056    the memory protection effect. */
00057 
00058 void lock_immutable_pages ( void );
00059 
00060 /* the str_immutable() function expects its parameter to be aligned to an 8-byte
00061    boundary, as well as zero-padded to the next 8-byte boundary, unless its a
00062    previous return value of itself. this function is a bit of a helper to ensure
00063    these alignment-constraints in case you dont know if your input meets these
00064    criteria. */
00065 
00066 /*@notnull@*/ /*@observer@*/ const char *str_immutable_unaligned (/*@notnull@*/ /*@returned@*/ const char *);
00067 
00068 #endif
Generated on Sun Sep 7 20:39:15 2008 for Curie by  1.5.4
